label: Length of all minor and major leaf lamina veins per unit area.
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the total length [PATO:0000122] of all leaf lamina veins [PO:0020138] to leaf [PO:0025034] area [PATO:0001323].
description: The length of all minor and major leaf lamina veins per unit leaf area.
comments: This trait records the length of all orders of leaf lamina veins, while the trait `leaf_major_vein_density` records only the length of major veins (primary, secondary and tertiary veins).
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman

description: A measure of vein density, which is the number of veins intersecting the perimeter of a square divided by the perimeter of the square.

label: Stem xylem vessel hydraulic mean diameter
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is a weighted arithmetic mean [STATO:0000398] diameter [PATO:0001334] of xylem vessels [PO:0025417] in a stem [PO:0009047], reflecting the greater relative contribution of wider vessels to hydraulic conductivity [EnvThes:22133] as described by the Hagen-Poiseuille equation [hupson:SCAIVPH_00000131] .
description: Hydraulic diameter (or hydraulically weighted diameter) is a weighted arithmetic mean diameter of stem xylem vessels, reflecting the greatest contribution of wide vessels to actual hydraulic conductivity. It is based on the Hagen-Poiseuille law, a fluid dynamics equation that describes laminar flow through a tube. It shows that a few large conduits transport an equal amount of water as many small ones, as flow rate is proportional to the 4th power of the conduit's diameter.
trait_category_encoded_x: plant morphology trait [TO:0000017]; vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470]; xylem vessel morphology trait [AusTraits]; water transport trait, hydraulic trait [AusTraits]

label: Stem xylem vessel lumen fraction
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of total xylem vessel [PO:0025417] lumen [PO:0025117] cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323] to stem [PO:0009047] cross-sectional area.
description: The fraction of a stem cross-section comprised of lumen, and calculated as the ratio of the total cross-sectional area comprised of xylem vessels (lumen fraction) to the total stem cross-sectional area.
exact_TRY: Stem conduit lumen cross-sectional area (vessels and tracheids) per stem sapwood cross-sectional are [TRY:172] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: plant morphology trait [TO:0000017]; vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470]; xylem vessel morphology trait [AusTraits]; water transport trait, hydraulic trait [AusTraits]

label: Stem xylem vessel multiple fraction
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of groups of xylem vessels [PO:0025417] to the total count of xylem vessels, with a value approximating 1 indicating a tendency towards solitary vessels.
description: Vmf; A vessel grouping index, calculated as the number of groups of vessels divided by the total number of vessels, where vessels are considered to be part of the same group if they are in contact with one another. A Vmf value approximating 1 denotes a tendency towards solitary vessels while a smaller value indicates a tendency of vessels to occur in clusters.
exact_TRY: Wood vessel grouping [TRY:276] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Stem non-lumen fraction
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is 1 minus the ratio [PATO:0001470] of total xylem vessel [PO:0025417] lumen [PO:0025117] cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323] to stem [PO:0009047] cross-sectional area.
description: The fraction of a stem cross-section comprised of non-lumen, and calculated as one minus the ratio of the total cross-sectional area comprised of xylem vessels (lumen fraction) to the total stem cross-sectional area.
exact_TRY: Wood (sapwood) cross-sectional fraction of Vessel (conduit) area [TRY:3018] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: xylem vessel wall fraction
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of xylem vessel [PO:0025417] cell wall [GO:0009505] cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323] to total xylem vessel cross-sectional area.
description: Fraction of xylem vessels comprised of cell wall, calculated as the ratio of xylem vessel cell wall cross-sectional area to total xylem vessel cross-sectional area.

label: Wood axial parenchyma fraction
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is the fraction of a cross-section [NCIT:C63795] of sapwood [PO:0004513] comprised of axial secondary xylem parenchyma [PO:0004533], calculated as ratio [PATO:0001470] of axial parenchyma cross-sectional area [PATO:0001323] to sapwood cross-sectional area.
description: The fraction of a cross-section of sapwood comprised of axial parenchyma. It is calculated as the ratio of total axial parenchyma cross-sectional area to sapwood cross-sectional area.
exact_TRY: Wood (sapwood) cross-sectional fraction of axial parenchyma area [TRY:3021] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Wood conduit fraction
description_encoded: A vascular tissue morphology trait [TO:0000470] which is the fraction of a cross-section [NCIT:C63795] of sapwood [PO:0004513] comprised of all water [CHEBI:15377] transport conduits (both tracheids [PO:0000301] and xylem vessels [PO:0025417]), calculated as the ratio [PATO:0001470] of total cross-sectional area [PATO:0001323] of conduits to sapwood cross-sectional area.
description: The fraction of a cross-section of sapwood comprised of all water transport conduits, including both xylem vessels and tracheids. It is calculated as the ratio of total conduit cross-sectional area to sapwood cross-sectional area.

label: Leaf work to punch
description_encoded: A leaf lamina [PO:0025060] strength [PATO:0001230] trait which is a measure of a leaf's [PO:0025034] compressive strength [SWEET:propPressure/CompressiveStrength; MESH:D019245]. It is the force [PATO:0001035] (work) required to punch a hole in a leaf lamina (fracture [SWEET:phenSolid/Fracture]) with a punch and die.
description: The force (work) required to punch a whole through a leaf lamina, generally with a punch and die. This is a measure of leaf compressive strength or toughness.
comments: Variation in methods used will mean that, in some cases, values are not perfectly comparable across studies. The expected units for this trait are listed as N/m, which is identical to J/m2; Newtons are a unit of force, while Joules are a unit of work, indicating how much work is done when force is applied.

label: Leaf work to shear
description_encoded: A leaf lamina [PO:0025060] strength [PATO:0001230] trait which is a measure of a leaf's [PO:0025034] compressive strength [SWEET:propPressure/CompressiveStrength; MESH:D019245]. It is the force [PATO:0001035] required to shear [SWEET:phenSolid/Shear] a leaf lamina with a pair of scissors.
description: The force (work) required to shear a leaf. This is a measure of leaf compressive strength or toughness that is equivalent to cutting a leaf with scissors.
comments: Variation in methods used will mean that, in some cases, values are not perfectly comparable across studies. The expected units for this trait, N is the same as J/m; Newtons are a unit of force, while Joules are a unit of work, indicating how much work is done when force is applied.

It is the force [PATO:0001035] required to shear [SWEET:phenSolid/Shear] a leaf lamina with a pair of scissors, scaled by leaf thickness [PATO:0000915].
description: The force (work) is required to shear a leaf, adjusted to leaf thickness; also referred to as 'fracture toughness'. This is a measure of leaf compressive strength or toughness that is equivalent to cutting a leaf with scissors.
comments: Variation in methods used will mean that, in some cases, values are not perfectly comparable across studies. The expected units for this trait, N/m is the same as J/m2; Newtons are a unit of force, while Joules are a unit of work, indicating how much work is done when force is applied.

label: Leaf work to tear
description_encoded: A leaf lamina [PO:0025060] strength [PATO:0001230] trait which is a measure ofa leaf's [PO:0025034] tensile strength [SWEET:propPressure/TensileStrength; MESH:D013718]. It is the force [PATO:0001035] required to tear or rip [SWEET:phenSolid/Rip] a leaf lamina.
description: The force (work) is required to tear/rip a leaf. This is a measure of leaf tensile strength.
comments: Variation in methods used will mean that, in some cases, values are not perfectly comparable across studies. The expected units for this trait, N is the same as J/m; Newtons are a unit of force, while Joules are a unit of work, indicating how much work is done when force is applied. (Work to tear is also sometimes reported in J.)

label: Bark modulus of elasticity
description_encoded: A bark [PO:0004518] physical quality [PATO:0002079] trait which is the bark's modulus of elasticity [SWEET:propPressure/ModulusOfElasticity], its resistance to being deformed [SWEET:phenSolid/Deform] elastically [PATO:0001031] (non-permanently) when a force [PATO:0001035] is applied.
description: A measure ofstem stiffness and elasticity, which is how much the bark is deformed elastically (bends) under stress. It is measured as the ratio of the force applied to bark per unit area (stress) to the bark's deformation (bending). Trait is also called Young's modulus for bark.
trait_category_encoded_x: plant morphology trait [TO:0000017]; plant structure strength trait [AusTraits]

label: Stem modulus of elasticity
description_encoded: A stem [PO:0009047] physical quality [PATO:0002079] trait which is the stem's modulus of elasticity [SWEET:propPressure/ModulusOfElasticity], its resistance to being deformed [SWEET:phenSolid/Deform] elastically [PATO:0001031] (non-permanently) when a force [PATO:0001035] is applied.
description: A measure of stem stiffness and elasticity, which is how much the stem is deformed elastically (bends) under stress. It is measured as the ratio of the force applied to stem per unit area (stress) to the stem's deformation (bending).  This is the modulus of a compound tissue made up of bark and wood (or xylem) and potentially pith and could also be called structural modulus of elasticity. Trait is also called Young's modulus for a stem.
close_TRY: Wood mechanical property: flexual stiffness, elasticity, rupture [TRY:1226] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: plant morphology trait [TO:0000017]; plant structure strength trait [AusTraits]

label: Xylem modulus of elasticity
description_encoded: A secondary xylem [PO:0005848] physical quality [PATO:0002079] trait which is the xylem's modulus of elasticity [SWEET:propPressure/ModulusOfElasticity], its resistance to being deformed [SWEET:phenSolid/Deform] elastically [PATO:0001031] (non-permanently) when a force [PATO:0001035] is applied.
description: A measure of wood stiffness and elasticity, which is how much wood (secondary xylem) is deformed elastically (bends) under stress. It is measured as the ratio of the force applied to wood per unit area (stress) to the stem's deformation (bending).  This is the modulus of elasticity explicitly for xylem (wood). Trait is also called Young's modulus for xylem.
close_TRY: Wood mechanical property: flexual stiffness, elasticity, rupture [TRY:1226] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: plant morphology trait [TO:0000017]; plant structure strength trait [AusTraits]

label: Modulus of rupture
description_encoded: A secondary xylem [PO:0005848] physical quality [PATO:0002079] trait which is the xylem [PO:0005352] cell wall's [GO:0009505] mechanical [MESH:D055595] bending strength [PATO:0001230], reported as the force [PATO:0001035] applied to a stem [PO:0009047] that causes it to stop bending and break (fail).
description: A measure of wood bending strength, which is the force per unit surface area applied to a length of bent stem (surface stress) that causes it to break. This is also the force required to rupture xylem vessels.
close_TRY: Wood mechanical property: flexual stiffness, elasticity, rupture [TRY:1226] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

keywords_x: water stress trait [TO:0000237]; xylem vessel [PO:0025417]; rupture [NCIT:C9445]

label: Leaf Jmax per unit leaf area
description_encoded: Maximum [NCIT:C25564] electron transport [MESH:D004579] rate [PATO:0000161] through the photosynthetic [GO:0015979] electron transport chain [GO:0022900], recorded per unit leaf area [TO:0000540]. The value is a parameter [STATO:0000034] derived from the portion of the photosynthesis A-ci response curve where ATP and NADPH production by the light reactions [GO:0019684] limits the rate of carboxylation [MOP:0000591].
description: The maximum potential photosynthetic electron transport rate, recorded per unit leaf area. This is a model-derived value, calculated from the portion of an A-ci response curve (curve showing the photosynthetic response to increase carbon dioxide concentrations) at high carbon dioxide concentrations where the photosynthetic rate is limited by the rate of  ATP and NADPH production by the light reactions.

label: Leaf Jmax per unit leaf mass
description_encoded: Maximum [NCIT:C25564] electron transport [MESH:D004579] rate [PATO:0000161] through the photosynthetic [GO:0015979] electron transport chain [GO:0022900], recorded per unit leaf dry mass [TO:0001014]. The value is a parameter [STATO:0000034]  derived from the portion of the photosynthesis A-ci response curve where ATP and NADPH production by the light reactions [GO:0019684] limits the rate of carboxylation [MOP:0000591].
description: The maximum potential photosynthetic electron transport rate, recorded per unit leaf dry mass. This is a model-derived value, calculated from the portion of an A-ci response curve (curve showing the photosynthetic response to increase carbon dioxide concentrations) at high carbon dioxide concentrations where the photosynthetic rate is limited by the rate of  ATP and NADPH production by the light reactions.

label: Leaf Jmax to leaf Vcmax ratio
description_encoded: The ratio [PATO:0001470] of a leaf's [PO:0025034] maximum [NCIT:C25564] electron transport [MESH:D004579] rate [PATO:0000161] to its maximum carboxylation [MOP:0000591] rate, reflecting the trade-off between photosynthetic gain and costs of excess energy dissipation, with the ratio affected by temperature, photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864] (light), and carbon dioxide [CHEBI:16526] concentration.
description: Ratio of photosynthetic electron transport capacity (Jmax) to maximum Rubisco activity (Vcmax). These are model-derived parameters, calculated from an A-ci response curve, reflecting, respectively the component of the curve where photosynthetic rates are limited by the light reactions versus low carbon dioxide concentrations.

label: Leaf maximum quantum yield
description_encoded: Maximum [NCIT:C25564] quantum yield [TO:0012004] of photosystem II [GO:0009539], as determined through chlorophyll fluorescence [GO:0090546]. Quantum yield is ratio [PATO:0001470] of photons [NCIT:C88112] absorbed to photons emitted [SIO:000384] through fluorescence.
description: A trait that indicates the health of photosystem II in a dark adapted leaf. Quantum yield is measured as the ratio of variable fluorescence (Fv) to maximum fluorescence (Fm), with a higher value indicating a healthier leaf. Variable fluorescence (Fv) is calculated as the difference between fluorescence in a leaf where all photsystems have been saturated by light (Fm) and a leaf in a dark-adapted state (minimum fluorescence; Fo).

label: Leaf resistance conductance under ambient conditions
description_encoded: The stomatal [PO:0008032] resistance [SWEET:propConductivity/Resistance] of plant leaves [PO:0025034] exposed to ambient [NCIT:C62306] photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864] levels and ambient atmospheric carbon dioxide [ENVO:01000451] concentrations [PATO:0000033], recorded per unit leaf area [TO:0000540]. Stomatal conductance is the rate [PATO:0000161] of carbon dioxide [CHEBI:16526] diffusion [NCIT:C82333] through stomata.
description: Leaf stomatal resistance under ambient light (photosynthetically active radiation) levels and ambient carbon dioxide concentrations. This is the original way leaf stomatal conductance was measured and reported and is still regularly used in environmental models and meteorology. An equation converts between resistance conductance and the molar values obtained through gas exchange readings ("Plants and Microclimate" by H.G. Jones (1992), page 55 and Appendix 3; "Elevated Carbon Dioxide Impacts on Soil and Plant Water Relations" by M.B. Kirkham (2011), page 149).

label: Hydraulic conductivity (Kh)
description_encoded: A stem [PO:0009047] water transport [GO:0006833] trait which is a measure of the rate [PATO:0000161] of water [CHEBI:15377] movement [NCIT:C37994] through a stem under a specific [NCIT:C38024] driving force [PATO:0001035] (water potential [EnvThes:22311] gradient [NCIT:C70693]), accounting for the stem length [PATO:0000122]. It is calculated as the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the water flow [NCIT:C41141] rate through the stem segment to the decrease in water potential across the stem segment, multiplied by the path length measured.
description: Kh; Measure of the efficiency of water flow through a stem segment which is calculated as the ratio of the water flow rate (kg/s) to the decrease in water potential (MPa) across the stem segment, multiplied by the stem length (m).
comments: This trait should not be confused with hydraulic conductance (kh), which is the ratio of water flow flow rate to the decrease in water potential across the stem segment, but IS NOT normalised to the stem length (kg/MPa/s).
units_uom: million kilogram metre per megapascal second
exact_TRY: Branch hydraulic conductance [TRY:3392] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Sapwood specific conductivity (Ks)
description_encoded: A stem [PO:0009047] water transport [GO:0006833] trait which is a measure of the rate [PATO:0000161] of water [CHEBI:15377] movement [NCIT:C37994] through a stem under a specific [NCIT:C38024] driving force [PATO:0001035] (water potential [EnvThes:22311] gradient [NCIT:C70693]), normalised to the diameter [PATO:0001334] of water transport tissues [CARO:0000043] and accounting for the stem length [PATO:0000122]. It is calculated as the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the water flow [NCIT:C41141] rate through the stem segment to the decrease in water potential across the stem segment, per unit sapwood [PO:0004513] cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323], multiplied by the path length measured.
description: Ks; Measure of the efficiency of water flow through a stem segment normalised to the sapwood cross-sectional area across which the flow is measured. It is calculated as the ratio of the water flow rate (kg/s) to the decrease in water potential across the stem segment (MPa), normalised to the sapwood cross sectional area (1/m2), then multiplied by the stem length (m).

label: Theoretical sapwood specific conductivity (Ks)
description_encoded: A stem [PO:0009047] water transport [GO:0006833] trait which is a theoretical [MESH:D008962] measure of the rate [PATO:0000161] of water [CHEBI:15377] movement [NCIT:C37994] through a stem under a specific [NCIT:C38024] driving force [PATO:0001035] (water potential [EnvThes:22311] gradient [NCIT:C70693]), calculated from the Hagen Poiseuille equation [hupson:SCAIVPH_00000131], then normalised to the diameter [PATO:0001334] of water transport tissues [CARO:0000043] and accounting for the stem length [PATO:0000122]. It is the calculated sapwood hydraulic conductance, per unit sapwood [PO:0004513] cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323], multiplied by the path length measured.
description: Theoretical Ks; A calculation of the theoretical flow rate of water (kg/s) along a stem for a given drop in pressure (MPa), normalised to the microscopically determined cross-sectional area without bark and pith (the diameter of water transport tissues). The calculation is based on Hagen-Poiseuille's law.

label: Leaf specific conductance (ks)
description_encoded: A leaf [PO:0025034] water transport [GO:0006833] trait which is a measure of the rate [PATO:0000161] of water [CHEBI:15377] movement [NCIT:C37994] through a leaf under a specific [NCIT:C38024] driving force [PATO:0001035] (water potential [EnvThes:22311] gradient [NCIT:C70693]), normalised to the leaf area [PATO:0001323]. It is calculated as the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the water flow [NCIT:C41141] rate through the leaf to the decrease in water potential across the leaf, per unit leaf area.
description: ks; Measure of how efficiently water is transported through the leaf, determined as the ratio of water flow rate through the leaf (kg/s) to the difference in water potential along the leaf axis (MPa), standardised to leaf area (1/m2). As this is a measure of "conductance" not "conductivity" the measurement is not normalised to the path length (the leaf length).

label: Leaf specific conductivity (Kl)
description_encoded: A stem [PO:0009047] water transport [GO:0006833] trait which is a measure of the rate [PATO:0000161] of water [CHEBI:15377] movement [NCIT:C37994] through a stem under a specific [NCIT:C38024] driving force [PATO:0001035] (water potential [EnvThes:22311] gradient [NCIT:C70693]), normalised to the branches' leaf [PO:0025034] area [PATO:0001323] and accounting for the stem length [PATO:0000122]. It is calculated as the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the water flow [NCIT:C41141] rate through the leaf to the decrease in water potential across the leaf, per unit leaf area, multiplied by the path length measured.
description: Kl; Measure of the efficiency of water flow through a stem segment across which the flow is measured, normalised to the total leaf area distil to the stem segment.  It is calculated as the ratio of the water flow rate (kg/s) to the decrease in water potential across the stem segment (MPa), normalised to the total leaf area (1/m2), then multiplied by the stem length (m).
comments: This trait is a variant of sapwood specific conductivity normalised to leaf area, usually by multiple Ks (sapwood specific conductivity) by Huber value. It is not a measure of conductivity through a leaf.

label: Osmotic potential
description_encoded: In a plant tissue [CARO:0000043], the potential energy [ENVO:2000016] of water [CHEBI:15377] molecules to flow [NCIT:C41141] across a semi-permeable [PATO:0000982] membrane [GO:0016020] due to the differences in solute [SIO:010418] concentration [PATO:0000033] across the membrane, such that the osmotic potential becomes more negative as the solute concentration increases or the cell water content decreases. Osmotic potential is equal to negative osmotic pressure [EnvThes:21558] and is also referred to as solute potential.
description: The potential energy of water molecules to move across a semi-permeable membrane due to differences in solute concentration across the membrane; solute potential

label: Osmotic potential at full tugor
description_encoded: A parameter [STATO:0000034] calculated from a pressure-volume curve, which is, for a shoot or leaf [PO:0025034], the osmotic potential (solute potential) when they are fully hydrated (relative water content = 100%). Osmotic potential is always negative and is the potential energy [ENVO:2000016] of water [CHEBI:15377] molecules to flow [NCIT:C41141] across a semi-permeable [PATO:0000982] membrane [GO:0016020] due to the differences in solute [SIO:010418] concentration [PATO:0000033] across the membrane.
description: A parameter calculated from a pressure-volume curve which is the osmotic potential (solute potential) in leaf cells at full turgor (when relative water content = 100%). Osmotic potential is the energy of water molecules to move across a semi-permeable membrane due to differences in solute concentration across the membrane and is least negative (largest) when plants are at full turgor.

It is an estimation of cell wall [GO:0009505] rigidity.

label: Photochemical peflectance index (PRI)
description_encoded: A remote sensing [EnvThes:21762] index [NCIT:C25390] of the efficiency [PATO:0001029] with which a whole plant [PO:0000003] uses photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864], calculated from the reflectance [EnvThes:21580] of radiation off the plant canopy [ENVO:01001242] at 531 nm (a xanthophyll [CHEBI:27325] band) and 570 nm (a reference band): PRI = (R531 - R570) / (R531 + R570). It is recorded with a spectroradiometer [MOSAIC:00000974] and a higher value indicates a higher radiation use efficiency.
description: Photochemical reflectance index measures plant responses to stress and the efficiency with which it uses photosynthetically active radiation, by indicating changes in carotenoid pigments in live foliage.  It is calculated from the reflectance of radiation off the plant canopy at 531 nm (a xanthophyll band) and 570 nm (a reference band): PRI = (R531 - R570) / (R531 + R570), with a higher value indicating higher radiation use efficiency.
trait_category_encoded_x: biological process trait, physiological process trait [TO:0000283]; photosynthetic trait [AusTraits]; photosystem performance [AusTraits]
keywords_x: reflectance [EnvThes:21580]; vegetation [EnvThes:20535]; vegetation reflectance [EnvThes:10118]; carotenoid [CHEBI:23044]; remote sensing [EnvThes:21762]; canopy [ENVO:01001242]; xanthophyll [CHEBI:27325]

label: Water band index
description_encoded: A remote sensing [EnvThes:21762] index [NCIT:C25390] of whole plant [PO:0000003] water status, which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the reflectance [EnvThes:21580] of radiation off the plant canopy [ENVO:01001242] at 970 nm to the reflectance at 900 nm, recorded with a spectroradiometer [MOSAIC:00000974], where a higher value indicates a higher canopy water [CHEBI:15377] content.
description: Water band index measures whole plant water status. It is the ratio of the reflectance of radiation off the plant canopy at 970 nm to the reflectance at 900 nm and a higher value indicates a higher canopy water content.
trait_category_encoded_x: biological process trait, physiological process trait [TO:0000283]; photosynthetic trait [AusTraits]; photosystem performance [AusTraits]
keywords_x: reflectance [EnvThes:21580]; vegetation [EnvThes:20535]; vegetation reflectance [EnvThes:10118]; remote sensing [EnvThes:21762]; canopy [ENVO:01001242]

label: Modified normalized difference vegetation index (modified NDVI)
description_encoded: A remote sensing [EnvThes:21762] index [NCIT:C25390] of whole plant [PO:0000003] vegetation status, which is a ratio [PATO:0001470] that considers the relative reflectance [EnvThes:21580] of red light versus short-wave infrared radiation (SWIR) off the plant canopy [ENVO:01001242] , where a higher value indicates greater vegetation health. The formula is: (SWIR - Red) / (SWIR + Red).
description: A remote sensing index of whole plant vegetation status, which is a ratio that considers the relative reflectance of red light versus short-wave infrared radiation (SWIR) off the plant canopy, where a higher value indicates greater vegetation health. The formula is: (SWIR - Red) / (SWIR + Red).
comments: Modified NDVI is generally measured from Landsat data.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; whole plant phenotype trait [AusTraits]

label: Plant growth form
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that summarises different components of a whole plant’s shape [PATO:0000052] and structure [PATO:0000141] into general groups [NCIT:C43359]. Characters that contribute to the plant form categories include the height [PATO:0000119] of the vegetative shoot system [PO:0025607], the distribution of leaves [PO:0025034] along the plant stem [PO:0009047], and the position [PATO:0000140] and count [NCIT:C25463] of stems and/or leaves relative to the ground surface.
description: The form of a plant, capturing a general sense of plant height and shape, which parts of a plant are woody versus herbaceous, the number of stems arising at ground level, and the distribution of leaves relative to the main stem.
comments: This definition of plant growth form is narrower than what is used by many other references. Here, information pertaining to where a plant grows is captured by `plant_growth_substrate`. Terminology about the shape and length of stems and distribution of leaves is included in `stem_growth_habit`. An indication of whether or not a plant is parasitic is presented in `parasitic`. Included in the list of plant growth forms are two terms that are exclusively used to describe Australian plants, mallee and hummock, and one, tussock, that is an important growth form of Australian grasses, but globally used less frequently.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman
close_TRY: Plant growth form [TRY:42] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Life form
description_encoded: Raunkiaer classification of life form, which is a feature of the whole plant [PO:0000003] defining the position [PATO:0000140] of the perennating meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055] or shoot apices [PO:0000037]) on the shoot system [PO:0009006], their distance [PATO:0000040] to the ground surface [sweetontology.net/realmSoil/Ground] and the protection afforded to survive the unfavourable season, or the production of seeds [PO:0009010] to avoid the unfavourable season.
description: Raunkiaer classification of life form, indicating the location of and protection provided to surviving meristematic tissue (buds) during the unfavourable (cold or dry) season.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman

label: Life history
description_encoded: Categorical description of the duration [PATO:0001309] of a plant’s lifespan (longevity [NCIT:C153298]), from seed germination [GO:0009845] to death [GO:0016265].
description: Categorical description of the duration of a plant’s lifespan, from germination to death.
comments: Studies will differ in the subset of terms they use to describe a plant’s life history, such that some researchers will distinguish between ephemeral and annual species, and other researchers will group these life history categories together under `annual`. In addition, only a subset of studies will use the term `short-lived perennial`; the majority will score all perennial plants as `perennial`. Rangeland studies and post-fire studies are those most likely to score species as `ephemeral` or `short-lived perennial`, as these are environments where perennial species’ lifespans are often divided into those that are short-lived due to environmental conditions and those that are able to persist through the environmentally unfavourable period.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman
exact_TRY: Plant lifespan (longevity) [TRY:59] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Lifespan
description_encoded: The duration [PATO:0001309] of a plant’s lifespan (longevity [NCIT:C153298]), from seed germination [GO:0009845] to death [GO:0016265].
description: Plant lifespan, the duration from germination to death. Lifespan refers to the death of both aboveground and belowground biomass.

label: Plant growth substrate
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which indicates either the substrate [EFO:0005061] on which a plant grows [GO:0040007] or, broadly, whether the plant grows in an aquatic [EnvThes:21785] or terrestrial [EnvThes:21880] habitat [ENVO:01000739]. Substrate is defined as the surface to which an organism is attached.
description: Trait broadly indicating where a plant is usually found, referencing the habitat in which a plant grows, the substrate to which a plant is attached, or a plant’s growth medium.
comments: Although the majority of vascular plants are `terrestrial`, for most taxonomic groups `plant growth substrate` is only recorded if a plant is not terrestrial. The exceptions are ferns and orchids, where both floras and individual researchers tend to specifically indicate which taxa are terrestrial. The values under this trait are recorded as part of `plant growth form` by many researchers, trait handbooks, and databases; they have been split out here, as the terms capturing what a plant is attached to do not generally describe the form of a plant.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]

label: Plant photosynthetic organ
description_encoded: A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the primary [NCIT:C25251] organ [PO:0009008] or tissue [CARO:0000043] a plant [PO:0000003] uses for photosynthesis [GO:0015979], most commonly a leaf [PO:0025034], cladode [PO:0025354], or phyllode [PO:0025335].
description: Trait indicating a plant’s primary photosynthetic organ or tissue.
comments: This trait is not intended to record the presence of primary versus secondary photosynthetic organs; only the primary photosynthetic organ should be keyed in. Many of the allowable values for this trait are frequently included under `leaf type` or `leaf form`. Here, we separate terms pertaining to the general form of the leaf (in the trait `leaf_type`) from those identifying the plant organ responsible for photosynthesis.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman
trait_category_encoded_x: biological process trait, physiological process trait [TO:0000283] > photosynthetic trait [AusTraits]; plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] > leaf morphology trait [TO:0000748]; stem morphology trait [TO:0000361]

label: Plant energy acquisition strategy
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is the mechanism [NCIT:C25343] plants use to obtain [NCIT:C52349] or produce [SIO:001106] energy [PATO:0001021] (carbohydrates [CHEBI:16646]).
description: Trait indicating the strategies used by a plant to obtain or produce energy (carbohydrates), including photosynthesis and various saprophytic and carnivorous energy acquistition mechanisms.
comments: Although the majority of vascular plants use photosynthsis to produce their own carbohydrates, this trait mostly included data for the few taxa that are not photosynthetic. See also the trait `parasitic` which captures data on whether or not plants are parasitic (or partially parasitic), forming haustoria to penetrate their host plant.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; whole plant phenotype trait [AusTraits]

label: Woodiness
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait which indicates whether the plant stem [PO:0009047] (the vegetative shoot system [PO:0025607]) is woody, with “woody” defined to include both plant stems with secondary xylem (true wood) [PO:0005848] and those with wood-like lignification [CHEBI:6457] (woodiness in monocots and ferns).
description: A binary trait, indicating whether or not a plant’s stems are woody, with woody broadly defined to include both `true wood` (secondary xylem) and taxa that do not produce secondary xylem (i.e. monocots and ferns) but have thick, stiff, robust lignified stems.
comments: This trait considers all species that have stiff lignified stems as `woody` and those that lack such stems as `herbaceous`. See the trait `plant woodiness detailed` for sub-categories of `woody` that indicate the extent and type of woodiness present in a plant stem.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman
close_TRY: Plant woodiness [TRY:38] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; whole plant phenotype trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: lignin [CHEBI:6457]; wood, secondary xylem [PO:0005848]; wood [NCIT:C93062]; shoot axis woodiness [FLOPO:0900038]

label: Detailed woodiness categories
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait which indicates the vertical [PATO:0001854] extent [PATO:0001708], distribution [PATO:0000060], and type [NCIT:C25284] of wood present in stems [PO:0009047], roots [PO:0009005], and reproductive shoot systems [PO:0025082], distinguishing between plants with secondary xylem (true wood) [PO:0005848] versus wood-like lignification [CHEBI:6457] (woodiness in monocots and ferns).
description: Trait indicating the extent, distribution, and type of secondary xylem (true wood) and wood-like lignification (woodiness in monocots and ferns) in stems, roots, and reproductive shoots.
comments: This trait documents in detail the degree and type of lignification in a plant's stems and roots (woodiness), while `plant woodiness` is a binary trait collapsing woodiness into a pair of values, `woody` versus `herbaceous`. Datasets that only use the terms `woody` versus `herbaceous` are only mapped to the binary trait; only datasets that explicitly indicate different levels of woodiness are mapped to `plant woodiness detailed`.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman
close_TRY: Plant woodiness [TRY:38] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

keywords_x: lignin [CHEBI:6457]; wood, secondary xylem [PO:0005848]; wood [NCIT:C93062]; shoot axis woodiness [FLOPO:0900038]

label: Physical defence structures
description_encoded: A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which indicates the plant structures [PO:0009011] used for defence [NCIT:C61556], including spine leaves [PO:0025173], spine stipules [PO:0025174], spine petiole [PO:0025613], thorns [PO:0025172], and prickles [PO:0025169].
description: The presence (or explicit absence) of specific physical defence structures on a plant, including spines, thorns, prickles, and sharp-tipped leaves.
comments: This trait identifies explicit physical defence structures on a plant. The trait `plant_spinescence` indicates the degree of defence afforded to plants, with values defined by Pérez-Harguindeguy et al. 2013 (doi:10.1071/BT12225).
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman

label: Plant climbing mechanisms
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates stem [PO:0009047] and leaf [PO:0025034] structures [PATO:0000141] and physical mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] a plant uses to climb [NCIT:C81002] up other plants or substrates.
description: Mechanisms plants use to climb, including both specialised leaf and stem adaptations and stem growth habits.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman

label: Plant succulence
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates whether or not any plant tissues [CARO:0000043] are succulent [FLOPO:0900041], indicating they are thick [PATO:0000591] and fleshy [PATO:0002351], generally storing water [CHEBI:15377] as a drought tolerance [TO:0000276] adaptation or filling with water as a salt tolerance [TO:0006001] adaptation.
description: Trait indicating whether the leaves or stems of a plant are thick and fleshy because they store water, generally an adaptation to arid or salty environments.
comments: Succulence generally has either a water storage function or is a mechanism to cope with (or thrive in) saline conditions. See the categorical trait `plant_tolerance_salt` for plant salt tolerance and salt avoidance strategies and the numeric trait `plant_tolerance_soil_salinity` for the soil salinity a plant can tolerate.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman

label: Stem growth habit
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates the structure [PATO:0000141] and 3-dimensional extent [PATO:0001710] of a plant’s vegetative shoot system [PO:0025607], including the position [PATO:0000140] of stems [PO:0009047], degree of branchiness [PATO:0002009], density [PATO:0001019] of branches [PO:0025073], and branch angles [PATO:0002326] relative to each other and the ground surface [sweetontology.net/realmSoil/Ground].
description: Trait characterising a stem’s structure and 3-dimensional extent, including the position of stems, degree of branchiness, density of branches, and branch angles relative to other branches and the ground surface.
comments: This trait captures how a plant explores 3-dimensional space, with trait values predominantly adjectives that modify the core plant growth forms.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman

label: Plant nitrogen fixation capacity
description_encoded: A trait which indicates whether a plant has the capacity to engage in symbioses [GO:0044403] with microorganisms [NCIT:C14329] (bacteria [NCIT:C14187], cyanobacteria [NCBITaxon:1117], and fungi [NCBITaxon:4751]) capable of nitrogen fixation [GO:0009399] and usually identified by nodulation [GO:0009877] on the plant roots [PO:0009005].
description: Binary variable describing whether or not a plant has the capacity for nitrogen fixatation, indicating it engages in symbioses with microorganisms (most commonly bacteria or cyanobacteria) that are capable of nitrogen fixation. Nitrogen fixation capacity is usually identified by nodules on the plant roots.

label: Plant parasitism status
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates if a plant is involved in a parasitic [ECOCORE:00000146] symbiosis [ECOCORE:00000022] where it forms haustorium [GO:0085035] on a host [GO:0018995] plant and the host plant provides all or some of its high energy [PATO:0001021] carbon [CHEBI:27594] compounds [NCIT:C43366], mineral nutrition (nutrients [CHEBI:33284]) and/or water [CHEBI:15377].
description: Trait indicating whether a plant forms haustoria and obtains part or all of its energy-rich carbon compounds (photosynthetic sugars), mineral nutrition and/or water directly from another plant (its host) in an interaction that does not benefit the host plant.
comments: Plants described as parasitic in the context of this trait always have haustoria, specialised organs that penetrate the host plants’s vascular bundles. The trait `root_strctures` documents symbiotic relationships with fungi. The trait `plant_energy_acquisition_strategy` documents specialised strategies or specialised organs or tissues plants use to obtain carbon or mineral nutrition.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Ian J. Wright, Peter Vesk, Gregory J. Jordan, Andy Leigh, Patricia Lu-Irving, Lily Dun, David Coleman

description: Months during which taxon produces fruit with mature seeds; keyed as a sequences of 12 Ns (not flowering) and Ys (flowering) starting with January.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Carl Gosper, Lydia Guja, Gregory J. Jordan, Mark Ooi, Karen Sommerville, Lily Dun
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; plant phenological trait [TO:0000933]
keywords_x: fruit [PO:0009001]; reproduction [GO_0000003]; whole plant fruit development stage [PO:0025500]

label: Pollination syndrome
description_encoded: A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on a taxon's [NCIT:C40098] flower morphology traits [TO:0000499] that indicates the taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely pollinate [GO:0009856] a flower [PO:0009046].
description: For a given taxon, the biotic vectors (including explicit taxa) or abiotic mechanisms that are most likely to pollinate its flowers, based on the taxon's flower morphology.
comments: The trait values reflect data currently in AusTraits. This trait could also include much more detailed trait values, where flower morphology suggests specific pollinators.
exact_TRY: pollination syndrome [TRY:29] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

exact_TOP_verb_x: flower pollination syndrome [TOP:333]

label: Pollination system
description_encoded: A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on a combination of a taxon's [NCIT:C40098] flower morphology traits [TO:0000499] (that suggest specific [NCIT:C38024] taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely pollinate [GO:0009856] a flower [PO:0009046]) and the pollinators actually observed visiting the taxon's flower.
description: For a given taxon, the biotic vectors (including explicit taxa) or abiotic mechanisms that are most likely to pollinate its flowers, based on a combination of possible pollinators observed visiting a taxon's flowers and the taxon's flower morphology.
close_TRY: pollination syndrome [TRY:29] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Vegetative reproduction ability
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is the ability [NCIT:C78209] of individual [EFO:0000542] plants to reproduce [GO:0000003] through asexual reproduction [GO:0019954] (vegetative reproduction).
description: A binary trait, indicating whether a plant taxon is able to reproduce and spread through the growth and division of vegetative material.
comments: For plants able to reproduce vegetatively, more detailed information about the mechanisms and structures that allow clonal spread is provided in the trait `clonal_spread_mechanism`.
exact_TRY: Plant vegetative regeneration capacity [TRY:344] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; whole plant phenotype trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: vegetative growth [EnvThes:21034]; clonal growth [EnvThes:21032]; regeneration [GO:0031099]; reproduction [GO_0000003]
exact_TOP_verb_x: whole plant reproduction type [TOP:123]

label: Clonal spread mechanism
description_encoded: A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the mechanism [NCIT:C25343] plants use for clonal growth [EnvThes:21032] (asexual reproduction [GO:0019954]) or for regeneration [GO:0031099] after a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373]
description: Mechanisms and structures (tissues, organs, or other structures) a plant uses to spread vegetatively, including the production of clones.
comments: See `vegetative_reproduction_ability` for a binary description of whether or not a plant can spread vegetatively. There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: `storage_organ` indicates the plant structures where a plant stores excess carbohydrates; these organs may or may not faciliate clonal spread; `bud_bank_location` indicates the location of meristematic tissue (buds) that allow regeneration following a disturbance or after an annual unfavourable season.
exact_TRY: Plant vegetative reproduction: clonal growth organ [TRY:356] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; plant morphology trait [TO:0000017]; morphology [PATO:0000051]; plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839]

label: Storage organ
description_encoded: A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the type [NCIT:C25284] of storage organ [EFO:0000997] a plant has, where a storage organ is a plant part (organ [PO:0009008], tissue [PO:0009007], or other plant structure [PO:0009011]) whose function [NCIT:C25518] is carbohydrate [CHEBI:16646] (energy [PATO:0001021]) storage.
description: Plant structures  (tissues, organs, or other structures) where a plant stores excess carbohydrates (energy). The stored energy may be used for future growth, including clonal spread and regrowth following an annual unfavourable season, or for regrowth following a disturbance event (including post-fire regeneration). Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.
comments: There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: `clonal_spread_mechanism` indicates mechanisms and structures a plant actually uses for vegetative spread; not all energy storage organs also allow vegetative spread; `bud_bank_location` indicates the location of meristematic tissue (buds) that allow regeneration following a disturbance or after an annual unfavourable season. See Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 (doi.org/10.1111/nph.14982) for detailed desciptions of recolonization ability and level of fire protection provided by each regeneration strategy.
references: Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 | Wigley 2020 | Tavşanoğlu1 & Pausas 2018
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; plant morphology trait [TO:0000017]; morphology [PATO:0000051]; plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839]
exact_TOP_verb_x: whole plant storage organ [TOP:166]

label: Bud bank location
description_encoded: The position [PATO:0000140] and distribution [PATO:0000060] of vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) on a plant [PO:0000003]. These may be buds that allow a plant to regrow following an unfavourable season or buds that survive [EnvThes:21064] a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373]. In particular, they may be meristematic tissue that survives a fire [ENVO:01000786] and allows the plant to resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following the fire.
description: The location of buds (meristematic tissue) on a plant that allows it to resprout following a fire, annual unfavourable season, or other disturbance event. Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.
comments: There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: `clonal_spread_mechanism` indicates mechanisms and structures a plant actually uses for vegetative spread; not all energy storage organs also allow vegetative spread; `storage_organ` indicates the plant structures where a plant stores excess carbohydrates. See Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 (doi.org/10.1111/nph.14982) for detailed desciptions of recolonization ability and level of fire protection provided by each regeneration strategy.
references: Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 | Wigley 2020 | Tavşanoğlu1 & Pausas 2018
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; whole plant phenotype trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: bud [PO:0000055]; spatial pattern, distribution [PATO:0000060]; location [NCIT:C25341]; resprout [AusTraits/fire ontology]

label: Sprout depth
description_encoded: The depth [PATO:0001595] below the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground] surface or height [PATO:] above the ground surface of vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprouts [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786].
description: Depth below the soil surface (negative number) or height above ground (positive number) from which buds (meristematic tissue) resprout following a disturbance, such as a fire.
close_TRY: Budbank height distribution [TRY:153] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]

label: Plant regeneration, non-fire disturbance
description_encoded: A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is the ability [NCIT:C78209] of individual [EFO:0000542] plants to regenerate [GO:0031099] (resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] from meristematic tissue [PO:0006079], buds [PO:0000055]) after a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373] other than a fire [ENVO:01000786].
description: Variable that indicates if a plant is able to regenerate (resprout) from a disturbance other than fire.
comments: This trait explicitly refers to regeneration ability following a disturbance event other than fire. See `bud_bank_location`, `clonal_spread_mechanism`, and `fire_response` for other information about a plant's ability to resprout.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: disturbance (event) [EnvThes:20373]; habitat disturbance [EnvThes:21488]; regeneration [GO:0031099]; tolerance [NCIT:C43414]; sensitivity [NCIT:C25201]; resprout [AusTraits/fire ontology]

label: Age of reproductive maturity
description_encoded: The time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] between seed germination [GO:0009845] and when a plant [PO:0000003] first reaches flowering stage [PO:0007616], indicating it is mature [PATO:0001701] and capable of reproduction [GO:0000003].
description: Age of plants when they first flower and are able to set seed, marking reproductive maturity.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; plant phenological trait [TO:0000933]

label: Age of secondary reprodctive maturity, post-fire
description_encoded: The time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] between a fire [ENVO:01000786] and when a plant [PO:0000003] that survives [EnvThes:21064] the disturbance event [EnvThes:20373] again reaches flowering stage [PO:0007616].
description: The time interval between a fire and when a taxon that survives the fire and is able to resprout again reaches flowers, indicating it has again reached reproductive maturity.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; plant phenological trait [TO:0000933]

label: Seed storage location
description_encoded: The location [NCIT:C25341] of a plant's [PO:0000003] seedbank [MESH:D000068098], indicating locations where mature [PATO:0001701] seeds [PO:0009010] are stored and remain viable [PATO:0000169] until germination [GO:0009845].
description: Location of a plant's seedbank, the location where mature seeds are stored and viable until germinating.
comments: Related traits include `seed_longevity`, `soil_seedbank`, `canopy_seedbank`, and `serotiny`.

description: Binary variable indicating whether mature seeds are retained in the plant canopy and remain viable in the plant canopy.

label: Seed maturation and release, timing
description_encoded: A life history trait which indicates the temporal pattern [EnvThes:21586] of seed [PO:0009010] maturation [TO:0002661] and seed release [NCIT:C42882] by a fruit [PO:0009001] or cone [strobilus; PO:0025083], including whether specific [NCIT:C38024] environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] trigger seed maturation and release.
description: A life history trait which indicates the pattern and timing of seed maturation and release from thr parent plant, including if seeds are only released in response to an environmental trigger, such as fire or flood.
comments: Related traits include  'seed_longevity', 'seed_storage_location', 'soil_seedbank', 'canopy_seedbank', and 'serotiny'

label: Serotiny
description_encoded: A fire response trait which indicates whether a fruit [PO:0009001] or cone [strobilus; PO:0025083] remains closed in the canopy [ENVO:01001242] after maturation [TO:0002661], with the seed [PO:0009010] only being released [NCIT:C42882] after a specific [NCIT:C38024] environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203], usually an environmental cue associated with a fire [ENVO:01000786].
description: Categorical variable describing whether a fruit or cone remains closed in the plant canopy after maturation until an environmental cue, usually a fire, triggers it to release its seeds.

description: Mechanisms that inhibit mature seeds from germinating and the environmental or experimental cues that allow a seed to break dormancy and germinate.

label: Seed germination treatment
description_encoded: The treatment [EFO:0000727] or experimental conditions [XCO:0000000] required for a high [NCIT:C25227] proportion [PATO:0001470] of seeds [PO:0009010] to germinate [GO:0009845] .
description: Treatment required for seed to display high germination rates. The data included in AusTraits are mostly from seed banks that have recorded the protocols they use to encourage seeds to germinate. The treatments may therefore be only loosely connected to the cues required for a species' to break dormancy.

label: Diaspore dispersal syndrome
description_encoded: A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on a taxon's [NCIT:C40098] seed morphology traits [TO:0000184] or fruit morphology traits [TO:0002629] that indicates the taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely disperse [OMIT: 0027297] seeds [PO:0009010] and fruit [PO:0009001] away from the parent plant.
description: Plant dispersal syndromes are generally assigned to species based on suites of diaspore characteristics associated with specific mechanisms of dispersal. Trait values are mostly given as the formal dispersal syndromes ending in 'chory', a suffix meaning 'a specified method of plant dispersal'.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Carl Gosper, Lydia Guja, Gregory J. Jordan, Mark Ooi, Karen Sommerville, Lily Dun
references: Pérez-Harguindeguy 2013 [doi.org/10.1071/BT12225] | Saatkamp 2018 [doi.org/10.1111/nph.15502] | Wigley 2020 [doi.org/10.1071/BT20048] | Leda Data Standards [https://uol.de/en/landeco/research/leda/standards] | Kew Seed Information Database [https://data.kew.org/sid/morphology.html]
exact_TRY: Dispersal syndrome [TRY:28] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Diaspore dispersal agents
description_encoded: The taxa [NCIT:C40098] (biotic vectors) and abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that disperse [OMIT: 0027297] seeds [PO:0009010] and fruit [PO:0009001] away from a parent plant.
description: Dominant diaspore dispersal agents, including both biotic agents (specific taxa) or abiotic mechanisms responsible for dispersing seeds (or other dispersal units) away from the parent plant.
comments: Allowable terms for biotic dispersal agents include taxa at both the species-level and much broader groupings, matching the different levels of resolution provided by researchers. Abiotic dispersal mechanisms can likewise be quite general or specific, depending on data availability.
reviewers: Elizabeth Wenk, Hervé Sauquet, Russell Barrett, Carl Gosper, Lydia Guja, Gregory J. Jordan, Mark Ooi, Karen Sommerville, Lily Dun
references: Pérez-Harguindeguy 2013 [doi.org/10.1071/BT12225] | Saatkamp 2018 [doi.org/10.1111/nph.15502] | Wigley 2020 [doi.org/10.1071/BT20048] | Leda Data Standards [https://uol.de/en/landeco/research/leda/standards] | Kew Seed Information Database [https://data.kew.org/sid/morphology.html]

label: Canopy light environment required for reproduction
description_encoded: A plant phenological [TO:0000933] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is an index [NCIT:C25390] that captures the level of photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864] required by plants for reproduction [GO:0000003].
description: The minimum light environment required by seedlings for reproduction, scaled from 0 to 8.
comments: 0 indicates `No direct light, extremely low levels of transmitted/reflected light, such as beneath dense fern or palm fronds close to ground level.`; 0.5 indicates `No direct light, very low levels of transmitted light`; 1 indicates `Rare or no exposure to direct light from lateral sources, and low levels of transmitted light.`; 2 indicates `Low lateral light and low-moderate transmitted light with <10% of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus low to moderate levels of transmitted light`; 3 indicates `Lowâ€“moderate lateral & moderate transmitted light, wit <5% exposure of the focal crown to vertical direct light, and <15 % of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate transmitted light.`; 4 indicates `Moderate lateral light & moderateâ€“high transmitted light, with 5 â€“ 10% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus 2-20% exposure of inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate to high levels of transmitted light.`; 5 indicates `Moderate vertical light and moderate-high lateral light, with 5 â€“ 20% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus one or both of, i. 10-40% exposure of 90-degree inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, ii. exposure to high levels of transmitted light`; 6 indicates `Moderate-High vertical and high lateral light, with 10-30% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, and lateral light exposure for > 40% of 90-degree inverted cone`, 7 indicates `High vertical and lateral light, with 30-80% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, or exposure to lateral sources of direct light for > 60 % of a 90-degree inverted cone encompassing the focal crown.`; 8 indicates `Full light exposure of crown, with > 80% of the vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light.`
references: Wells 2012, PhD Thesis UQ, no doi
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; plant phenological trait [TO:0000933]
keywords_x: photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864]; reproduction [GO:0000003]; response to stimulus [GO:0050896]

label: Canopy light environment required for seedling establishment
description_encoded: A plant phenological [TO:0000933] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is an index [NCIT:C25390] that captures the level of photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864] required by plants for seed germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410].
description: The minimum light environment required by seedlings for establishment, scaled from 0 to 8.
comments: 0 indicates `No direct light, extremely low levels of transmitted/reflected light, such as beneath dense fern or palm fronds close to ground level.`; 0.5 indicates `No direct light, very low levels of transmitted light`; 1 indicates `Rare or no exposure to direct light from lateral sources, and low levels of transmitted light.`; 2 indicates `Low lateral light and low-moderate transmitted light with <10% of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus low to moderate levels of transmitted light`; 3 indicates `Low-moderate lateral & moderate transmitted light, wit <5% exposure of the focal crown to vertical direct light, and <15 % of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate transmitted light.`; 4 indicates `Moderate lateral light & moderateâ€“high transmitted light, with 5-10% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus 2-20% exposure of inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate to high levels of transmitted light.`; 5 indicates `Moderate vertical light and moderateâ€“high lateral light, with 5-20% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus one or both of, i. 10-40% exposure of 90-degree inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, ii. exposure to high levels of transmitted light`; 6 indicates `Moderate-High vertical and high lateral light, with 10-30% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, and lateral light exposure for > 40% of 90-degree inverted cone`, 7 indicates `High vertical and lateral light, with 30-80% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, or exposure to lateral sources of direct light for > 60 % of a 90-degree inverted cone encompassing the focal crown.`; 8 indicates `Full light exposure of crown, with > 80% of the vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light.`
references: Wells 2012, PhD Thesis UQ, no doi
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; plant phenological trait [TO:0000933]
keywords_x: photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864]; seed germination [GO:0009845]; response to stimulus [GO:0050896]; seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410]

label: Post-fire establishment
description_encoded: A seed's [PO:0009010] longevity [EnvThes:22228], expressed as a categorical variable [STATO:0000252], where seed longevity is the time interval (duration [PATO:0001309]) between when a seed matures [PATO:0001701] and it is no longer able to germinate [GO:0009845].
description: Trait capturing post-fire time frame during which species establishes. The selection of trait values does not distinguish between intermediate age and mature vegetation, as this level of detail is rarely provide in datasets.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: habitat disturbance [EnvThes:21488]; fire [ENVO:01000786]; sensitivity [NCIT:C25201]; requirement [NCIT:C25652]; seed germination [GO:0009845]; recruitment [Cerrado:ccon#Recruitment]; response to stimulus [GO:0050896]; duration [PATO:0001309]; seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410]

label: Post-fire recruitment
description_encoded: A fire response trait which indicates whether or not a taxon [NCIT:C40098] has high [NCIT:C25227] seed [PO:0009010] germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410] after a fire [ENVO:01000786].
description: A trait indicating whether a taxon has high seed germination and seedling establishment following a fire.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: habitat disturbance [EnvThes:21488]; fire [ENVO:01000786]; sensitivity [NCIT:C25201]; requirement [NCIT:C25652]; seed germination [GO:0009845]; recruitment [ccon#Recruitment]; response to stimulus [GO:0050896]; seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410]

label: Fuel bed bulk density.
description_encoded: Fuel bed bulk density (volume density [PATO:0001353]), which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the mass [PATO:0000125] of the fuel bed divided by the fuel bed volume [PATO:0000918]; the term `fuel bed` refers to the accumulated plant litter [ENVO:01000628] on the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground], as this is the fuel [CHEBI:33292] that is burnt in a ground fire [ENVO:01000786].
description: The density of plant litter accumulated on the ground, the fuel bed. It is calculated as the ratio of the mass of the fuel bed to the fuel bed volume. This trait should be measured on plant litter from a single taxon.
comments: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a "community level" trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document fuel bed bulk density in experimental situations.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]
measured_characteristic_x: mass [PATO:0000125]; mass fraction [ECSO:00000619]; ratio, proportion [PATO:0001470]; volume density [PATO:0001353]

label: Fuel comsumption by fire
description_encoded: For a given taxon [NCIT:C40098], the proportion [PATO:0001470] of plant biomass [ENVO:01000155] (fuel [CHEBI:33292]) that is consumed by a fire [ENVO:01000786].
description: Proportion of available plant biomass (live and dead) that is consumed by fire. This trait should be measured on biomass from a single taxon.
comments: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a "community level" trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document fuel consumption in experimental situations.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]

label: Fire rate of spread
description_encoded: For a given taxon [NCIT:C40098], the horizontal [PATO:0001855] speed [PATO:0000008] of fire [ENVO:01000786] movement [NCIT:C37994].
description: The horizontal rate of fire spread.
comments: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a "community level" trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to documents rates of fire spread in experimental situations.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]
measured_characteristic_x: length [PATO:0000122] < 1-D extent [PATO:0001708] < size [PATO:0000117]; per unit time [EnvThes:22005]; ratio, proportion [PATO:0001470]

label: Fire response
description_encoded: A fire response trait which indicates whether or not individual [EFO:0000542] plants [PO:0000003] from a taxon [NCIT:C40098] or population [PCO:0000001] are killed or have vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] that causes 100% leaf scorch, with fire severity index [EnvThes:22120] an important contextual variable.
description: Trait indicating whether mature individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to fire that causes 100% leaf scorch.  Species where at least 70% of plants resprout are designated `resprouters`, while those where fewer than 30% of plants resprout are designated as `fire killed`. Species with an intermediate response have a mixed fire response, and are coded as `fire_killed resprouts`.
comments: This trait is narrowly applicable only to taxa that experience fire; see the trait `fire_exposure_level` for trait values related to species whose strategy is to avoid fire.
exact_TRY: Species tolerance to fire; Plant resprouting capacity [TRY:318; TRY:819] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]

label: Fire response, detailed

description: Detailed categories indicating whether mature individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to fire that causes 100% leaf scorch.
comments: This trait is narrowly applicable only to taxa that experience fire; see the trait `fire_exposure_level` for trait values related to species whose strategy is to avoid fire.

label: Proportion resprouting individuals
description_encoded: A fire response trait which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of individuals [EFO:0000542] in a population [PCO:0000001] that have vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprouts [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] to the count of individuals in the population before the fire.
description: Proportion of individuals in a population that survive a fire and resprout following a fire.

measured_characteristic_x: count [NCIT:C25463]; has number of [PATO:0001555]; dimensionless ratio [STATO:0000300]; ratio, proportion [PATO:0001470]

label: Fire response, juvenile plants
description_encoded: A fire response trait which indicates whether or not juvenile [PATO:0001190] plants [PO:0000003] from a taxon [NCIT:C40098] or population [PCO:0000001] are killed or have vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprouts [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786], with fire severity index [EnvThes:22120] an important contextual variable.
description: Trait indicating whether juvenile individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to fire.

label: Fire response on plant maturity
description_encoded: A fire response trait which indicates whether the maturity [PATO:0000261] status of plants [PO:0000003] changes following a fire [ENVO:01000786], with plants being killed, surviving and remaining mature [PATO:0001701], or surviving and reverting to juvenile [PATO:0001190].
description: Trait indicating if a plant remains reproductively mature following a fire or if the plant reverts to a juvenile life stage following a fire.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: habitat disturbance [EnvThes:21488]; fire [ENVO:01000786]; tolerance [NCIT:C43414]; sensitivity [NCIT:C25201]; requirement [NCIT:C25652]; resprout [AusTraits/fire ontology]; killed [AusTraits/fire ontology]; maturity [PATO:0000261]; juvenile [PATO:0001190]

label: Fire response, stem count ratio
description_encoded: A fire response trait which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of stems [PO:0009047] per individual [EFO:0000542] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] to the count of stems per individual before the fire, recorded for taxa that have multiple stems emerging from the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground].
description: Ratio of stem count post-fire to stem count pre-fire at an individual or population level. This trait is appropriate to score for plants that have many stems from the base (shrubs, herbs, graminoids) where the number of stems before and after fire is censused. It is a continuous measure of resprouting strength conditioned on initial size.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]

label: Fire exposure level
description_encoded: A fire response trait indicating why the shoot systems [PO:0009006] of some taxa [NCIT:C40098] might not be exposed [NCIT:C17941] to fire [ENVO:01000786] or scorched by fire, even when a fire occurs nearby.
description: Trait indicating habitat (or microhabitat) variation that protects the shoot system of some taxa from being exposed to fire and scorched by the fire, even when a fire burns nearby.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]

label: Time from fire to fruiting
description_encoded: A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until a taxon [NCIT:C40098] produces fruit [PO:0009001].
description: The time interval from a fire until a plant produces fruit.
trait_category_encoded_x: life history trait [AusTraits]; fire response trait [AusTraits]
keywords_x: fire [ENVO:01000786]; whole plant fruit development stage [PO:0025500]; time interval [SWEET:propTime/TimeInterval]

label: Leaf smoulder duration
description_encoded: A fire response trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] of the portion of fire [ENVO:01000786]-induced combustion [NCIT:C157201] process from the time when a flame [ENVO:01000789] is no longer visible until smoulder combustion ends.
description: Smoulder duration for a single leaf, which is the time from the end of the last visible flame until the glowing phase dies out.

label: Leaf flame duration

description: Flame duration for a single leaf, which is the time from the first visible flame until the last visible flame.

label: Leaf flame and smoulder duration
description_encoded: A fire response trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] of the entire fire [ENVO:01000786]-induced combustion [NCIT:C157201] process from the time of the start of combustion until smoulder combustion ends.
description: For a single leaf, the sum of flame duration and smoulder duration, which is the time from the first visible flame until the glowing phase dies out.

label: Fire time to ignition
description_encoded: A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] from a leaf's [PO:0025034] exposure [NCIT:C17941] to a flame [ENVO:01000789] until the leaf ignites.
description: For a single leaf, the time from an ignition source contacting the leaf until ignition occurs.

label: Plant resource requirements and tolerance
description_encoded: An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on the environmental conditions in which they survive and thrive, including their tolerance of, sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to, and requirement [NCIT:C25652] for certain resource availabilities [EnvThes:21497], including water [CHEBI:15377] availability and soil [ENVO:00001998] nutrient [CHEBI:33284] content and salinity [PATO:0085001].
description: Classification scheme of plant resource requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa based on their water, soil nutrient, and soil salinity requirements and tolerances.
close_TRY: Species tolerance to salt [TRY:1254];  Species tolerance to drought [TRY:595] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

label: Plant flood regime rsponse
description_encoded: An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on the depth [PATO:0001595], duration [PATO:0001309] and frequency [PATO:0000044] of inundation [SWEET:phenSystem/Inundation] a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate. It incorporates their ability to tolerate or respond to fluctuations in flooding [ENVO:01000710] and drying, including growth [GO:0040007] and seed germination [GO:0009845].
description: Classification scheme of plant flood regime requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa into seven groups based on their germination and growth responses to flood regimes.
references: Brock and Casanova 1997 [url:www.researchgate.net/profile/Michelle-Casanova-4/publication/264240348_Plant_life_at_the_edge_of_wetlands_ecological_responses_to_wetting_and_drying_patterns/links/53d5a1230cf228d363ea0d9b/Plant-life-at-the-edge-of-wetlands-ecological-responses-to-wetting-and-drying-patterns.pdf]; Casanova and Brock 2000 [url:link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1009875226637]

label: Plant water-logging tolerance
description_encoded: An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] that a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate water-logged soils, an indication of a plant's sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to flood [ENVO:01000710] conditions. Soil [ENVO:00001998] is considered water-logged if it is saturated [NCIT:C61427] with water [CHEBI:15377], limiting the plant root's [PO:0009005] ability to respire [GO:0045333] due to a lack of soil oxygen [CHEBI:15379].
description: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate water-logged soils.

description: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate being under water.

label: Plant salt tolerance strategy
description_encoded: An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on their salinity [PATO:0085001] tolerance [TO:0006001], reflecting the duration [PATO:0001309] and concentration [PATO:0000033] of salt [CHEBI:24866] exposure that a plant is able to tolerate.
description: Classification scheme of plant salt-tolerance categories, categorising taxa based on their tolerance of or sensitivity to salty soils, salt spray, or salt water.
comments: The trait `soil_salinity_tolerance` documents actual soil salinity levels taxa can tolerate. The trait `plant_type_by_resource_use` has some overlapping values, but focuses on terms to describe a plant's overall resource tolerances/requirements, while this trait focuses on terms associated with salinity tolerances/requirements.

label: Plant calcium sensitivity

description: Classification scheme of plant soil calcium tolerance, indicating if plants are intolerant of basic soils (calcifuge) or tolerant of basic soils, such as calcareous sands and limestone derived soils (calcicole).
